title: Blogging about AI with Jupyter and Quarto
text:
Why use Jupyter and Quarto?
The fast.ai team recommends to work in Jupyter and blog using Quarto. Their nbdev2 tool also makes use of Quarto. We can work on a notebooks in Jupyter, then run them through nbdev2 and Quarto to produce software libraries, documentation, apps, blog posts, papers, and even books.
See also:

nbdev+Quarto: A new secret weapon for productivity

text:
Polar Line Plot
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def myrange(start, stop, step=1):
    n = round((stop-start)/step) + 1
    return np.linspace(start, stop, n)

r = myrange(0, 4, 0.01)
theta = 3 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks(myrange(1, 4))
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()




Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis

title: Blogging about AI with Jupyter and Quarto
text:
My setup
I am running the AI tools on my home PC, with Debian GNU/Linux and an NVIDIA GPU.
The following setup is not recommended unless you know what you’re doing with Linux, and not even then! Check the fast.ai docs and (Lesson 1 of Practical Deep Learning for Coders)[] for some more sensible options to get started.
I decided to go old school and install the necessary Python modules under /usr/local with pip. This way I can use my AI tools directly from the shell, like other programs on the system.
It’s not safe to run pip as root. It will merrily remove files from Debian-packaged python modules, and mess up the system. To avoid this, I changed permissions so that my regular user account can write to everything under /usr/local via the staff group.
I might write more about my setup in a separate blog post.

Adding this post to the blog
I had already started writing this post in a Jupyter Lab notebook blogging.ipynb. Now I needed to put it in the right place, so I made a directory for it:

!mkdir -pv blog/posts/blogging

mkdir: created directory 'blog/posts/blogging'


I then moved this notebook blogging.ipynb into that new blog/posts/blogging directory, directly in Jupyter Lab. There was no need to close the notebook.

title: Blogging about AI with Jupyter and Quarto
text:
Previewing the blog
We can preview the blog, by running this in a terminal:
quarto preview blog
Don’t run it in a Jupyter cell, because it doesn’t exit and will hang Jupyter!
I’m using a few extra options that suit my setup:
quarto preview blog --no-browser --port 4242
